Disc Structure
There is a large number of cylinders which are concentric.
Each cylinder has a vertically stacked set of tracks.
Each track is divided into a number of sectors.
Newer discs have zones and tracks in outer zones have larger
number of sectors than those in inner zones. Outer zones have
around 100 sectors per track.
Similarly, the number of cylinders per disc has also been
increasing and can be several thousands.

cm. Science—Philosophy. I. Title. II. From time to time, scientiﬁc work itself was affected, especially in the social sciences. Science is seen as something found in all human cultures, even though the
word is a Western invention. Science is something that descends from speciﬁc people
and places, and especially from a key collection of Europeans, including
Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo, Descartes, Boyle, and Newton, who all lived
in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
To set things up this way is to see science as unlike the kinds of investigation and knowledge that routinely go along with farming, architecture,
and other kinds of technology. Science, it was argued, is too creative and unpredictable a process for there to
be a recipe that describes it—this is especially true in the case of great scientists like Newton, Darwin, and Einstein. Empiricism encompasses a diverse family of philosophical views, and debates within the empiricist
camp can be intense. Empiricism
wins; looking to experience is a sure-ﬁre guarantee of getting things right.
Those who are tempted to think that no problems remain might consider
a cautionary tale that follows up the Snow story. Empiricists do not deny that reasoning, including very elaborate reasoning, is needed to make sense of what we
observe. Empiricism is supposed to urge that
people be distrustful of authority and go out to look directly at the world.
But of course this is a fantasy. Galileo vigorously made the case for the literal truth of the Copernican system, as opposed to its mere usefulness. Galileo used telescopes (which he did not
invent but did improve) to look at the heavens, and he found a multitude
of phenomena that contradicted Aristotle and the Scholastic view of the
world. Galileo’s work eventually aroused the ire of the pope; he
was forced to recant his Copernican beliefs by the Inquisition and spent his
last years under house arrest. Two other introductory books are worth mentioning, though. There
are several good books that focus on particular personalities. Empiricists like Locke and Hume insisted that experience is our only way of ﬁnding out what the world is like. Some problems would be solved, and other problems would be rejected as meaningless. . . . Science itself was seen as just a more complex
and sophisticated version of the sort of thinking, reasoning, and problemsolving that we ﬁnd in everyday life—and completely unlike the meaningless blather of traditional philosophy.
So let us now look at the logical positivists’ picture of science and of the
role of philosophy in a scientiﬁc worldview. Neurath thought this was a mistake
and argued that terms referring to many ordinary physical objects are in the
observational part of language. As Schlick once put it, “what every scientist seeks, and seeks alone, are . . . Neurath said that in our attempts to
learn about the world and improve our ideas, we are “like sailors who have
to rebuild their ship on the open sea.” The sailors replace pieces of their
ship plank by plank, in a way that eventually results in major changes but
which is constrained by the need to keep the ship aﬂoat during the process.
2.4 Problems and Changes

to many challenges. 4). In practice, science seems to have some effective ways of working out

ordinary world of observables there is a special and superior realm, pure
and perfect. Science uses unusual theoretical concepts (which look initially like attempts to refer to hidden things) as a way of discovering and describing subtle patterns in the observable realm. There

with his solution to the demarcation problem. We should not expect to be able to go

Some of Popper’s ideas are useful in trying to answer this question. A problem may have

in the previous section). There
might also be practical reasons for choosing that design if we are very familiar with it. Science textbooks are
more cautious about laying out recipes for science than they used to be, but
descriptions of the hypothetico-deductive method are still fairly common.

be an inﬁnite number of competing theories. Science tries to formulate and handle ideas in such a

“OK, the paradigm has shifted. In Kuhn’s theory of science, the big changes in how scientists see the world—the “revolutions” that science undergoes every now
and then—occur when one paradigm replaces another. This achievement might be a strikingly successful experiment, such as Mendel’s experiments with peas, which eventually became the basis of modern genetics. Whatever it is, this achievement is a source
of inspiration to others; it suggests a way to investigate the world. . . , and

is so impressive that a tradition of further work starts to grow up around
it. A problem might, for all we know, have no solution. Normal science

with new cases. The transition to a crisis
is almost like a phase transition, like the change of a substance from solid
to liquid during melting. Normal science is structured in
a way that makes its own destruction inevitable, but only in response to the
right stimulus. Normal science is work aimed at extending and reﬁning the paradigm. Normal scientists extend their paradigm both theoretically and
experimentally. Kuhn held that, in general, a single paradigm will dominate its ﬁeld. “Look,” he said again. These two processes happen in sequence, within each
scientiﬁc ﬁeld. Science as a whole is a result of their interaction and of
nothing less.

is no steady buildup of some useful commodity like truth as science goes
along. So far, this does not tell us whether Kuhn was a
relativist about these standards. Science is not heading toward a ﬁnal paradigm that
is superior to all others. This claim was made when Kuhn confronted the question
of how to understand progress in science.
Kuhn gave two very different kinds of explanation for the apparent
large-scale progress we see in science, and these two explanations are intertwined with each other in complex ways. Science will inevitably appear to exhibit progress because each ﬁeld has one paradigm per
time, the victors after each revolution will naturally view their victory as
progressive, and science is insulated from outside criticism. When paradigms change, ideas change. There
is an accumulation (maybe) of a kind of problem-solving power. Science owes its strength
to an interaction between the ordered cooperation and single-mindedness
of normal science, together with the ability of these ordered behavioral patterns to break down and reconstitute themselves in revolutions. Science is a form of organized behavior with
a speciﬁc social structure, and science seems only to thrive in certain kinds
of societies. Feyerabend’s most important work (1975)
was written, he said, as a kind of letter to Lakatos, but Lakatos died in

of Kuhn’s historical arguments. Fine, so far. We should then separately (or
in footnotes) point out places where the rational reconstruction is not an
accurate description of what actually went on. First,

was right to see a mismatch between the rhetoric and the reality of Lakatos’s
views. Not really. And for Lakatos, the hard core never changes. There
can be some movement of ideas in and out of the hard core. We should accept (perhaps cautiously) the theories that have the highest level of problem-solving power. Science might be better served by some kind of mechanism in which the ﬁeld hedges its bets. Feyerabend, like many key ﬁgures in this
book, was born in Austria. Feyerabend was initially inﬂuenced by Popper, with whom he worked for a year in the 1950s. Feyerabend’s most famous work was his 1975 book Against
Method. Feyerabend found the
opposite: an incitement for scientists to become orderly and mechanical.
Feyerabend saw Kuhn as glorifying the mind-numbing routine of normal
science and the rigid education that Kuhn thought produced a good normal scientist. Feyerabend saw this
ambiguity in Kuhn’s writing as a deliberate rhetorical device for insinuating into the reader a positive picture of the most mundane type of science.
For Feyerabend, the mind-set that Kuhn encouraged also leads to a lack of
concern for the moral consequences of scientiﬁc work.
Feyerabend also argued that Kuhn was factually wrong about the role
of normal science in history. There are always imaginative individuals trying out new ideas.
Feyerabend was not, as he is sometimes portrayed, an “enemy of science.” He was an enemy of some kinds of science. Science, for

of challenging rather than following the lessons of observation.

as ubiquitous. Feyerabend claims that because some principle or rule may
go wrong, we should completely ignore it. The train might crash. Or if you caught
a different train, you might meet the love of your life on the way. Science
“may proﬁt” from all kinds of strange decisions, but “may” is not enough.
So we have a mixture of good and bad argument in Feyerabend’s treatment of these issues. We should keep in mind that
“rules are made to be broken” in Feyerabend’s view. Feyerabend argued that we can often only perceive the limitations
of our current perspective if we try to step outside it, at least temporarily.
Achieving a novel, external perspective on ideas that we usually assume
uncritically is often the beginning of progress. Feyerabend gives a recipe that, if it
was followed, would lead to the accumulation of an ever-increasing range
of scientiﬁc ideas being discussed in every ﬁeld. But aside from that,
there is no way for an idea to be taken off the table. Feyerabend never gave a satisfactory answer to this question.
If what we really want from science is to have a community full of lively,
imaginative discussion, then Feyerabend’s recipe for scientiﬁc behavior is
an appropriate one. Science then would be very similar to art. Science needs the invention of alternatives, but it also needs
mechanisms for pruning the range of options and abandoning some. If one framework seems not to be working, then we
try another. Feyerabend is an interesting
case. We should
not think that there is a simple choice between the one-process camp (Popper, Quine, and Feyerabend in a sense) and the two-process camp (Carnap,
Kuhn, Lakatos, Laudan, and Friedman). Options proliferated, including radical options. This, Merton claimed, is the only property right recognized in science. Galileo fought tooth and nail over
recognition for various ideas of his. There are some exceptions to the general tendency;
the most famous is the tremendously polite and gentlemanly non-dispute
between Charles Darwin and Alfred Russell Wallace over the theory of
evolution by natural selection in the nineteenth century. As Merton says, the moral fervor seen in these debates,
even on the part of those with no direct involvement, suggests that a basic
community standard is operating.
Merton argued that the reward system of science mostly functions to
encourage original thinking, which is a good thing. . . (etc.). There are not enough laws and constants for everyone to
get one. As Merton himself noted, the reward
system can be at tension with the norms. At least in some of his work,
Merton assumed a view of scientiﬁc theories that is close to logical empiricism—theories are basically networks of predictive generalizations.
The newer sociology embraced Kuhn, holism about testing, incommensurability, new ideas about observation, and various speculative views about
scientiﬁc language. MacKenzie argued that a body of biological, mathematical, and social ideas was well matched to the “interests” of the ambitious, reformist English middle classes. MacKenzie was cautious. Many sociologists accepted this label, but we need to be careful. There are so many
deﬁnitions of relativism ﬂoating around that the sense of relativism embraced by the sociologists need not be the same as that used by commentators and critics. Unfortunately, that is what happened in sociology of science. It is different. Neither we alone nor reality alone is “responsible” for human knowledge. . . . There
seems to be no place in the picture for the responsiveness of scientiﬁc belief to the real structure of the world being investigated. Science itself, and mainstream theorizing about science and knowledge, have helped to keep
women in a “second-class” position as thinkers, knowers, and intellectual
citizens. Feminist thinking about science was often allied with work in the sociology of science,
and Kuhn, Feyerabend, and Wittgenstein were also seen as helpful. Feminism in general aims to understand
and ﬁght against inequalities between the sexes, with respect to political
rights, economic standing, and social status. Feminist epistemology
also goes beyond criticism to make suggestions about reform—how to
make science better at ﬁnding out about the world (if that goal is to be retained), and also how to make science more socially responsible.
In discussing some of the options here, I will modify some categorizations used by Sandra Harding (1986, 1996). Science will beneﬁt from taking more seriously the
ideas developed by people with this special point of view. Science is rational to the extent that it chooses theories from a diverse pool of options reﬂecting different points of view, and makes its choice via a critical dialogue that reaches
consensus without coercion. Feminists accept that other differences, especially class differences and ethnic differences, may have as much of an effect as do gender
differences, or even more than that. Feminists themselves (including Keller) are also
very wary about the possibility of contributing to a stereotyping of female

144 Chapter Nine

contributions to scientiﬁc thinking. Feminists have
sometimes suggested that women are, on the whole, less competitive and
more cooperative than men, though many feminists would now want to
avoid simple generalizations of this kind (Miner and Longino 1987). Science Studies is rather hostile toward the idea of explaining patterns in scientiﬁc change in terms of relations between scientiﬁc theories and the
structure of the world. There
is also a mass of material about the Sokal hoax on the World Wide Web; see especially Sokal’s site: http://physics.nyu.edu/faculty/sokal/.

10
••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

Naturalistic Philosophy in Theory and Practice

10.1 What Is Naturalism?

What kind of theory should the philosophy of science try to develop? Science is
used as a resource for philosophy, not as a replacement.

152 Chapter Ten

What might be examples of these questions that remain relevant in naturalistic philosophy but which are not directly addressed within science itself? Science is a resource for settling philosophical
questions, rather than a replacement for philosophy or the source of philosophy’s agenda.
I should note that I am not arguing that all work done by philosophers
should be naturalistic in this sense. There are other roles for
philosophy as a discipline as well. We should try to achieve (1) a general understanding of
how humans gain knowledge of the world around them, and (2) an understanding of what makes the work descended from the Scientiﬁc Revolution
different from other kinds of investigation of the world. There
could, in principle, be an institution that looked like what we call “science” but in which there was no genuine responsiveness to the world. Empiricists have agreed that observation is our
source of knowledge about the world. This looks like trouble. It is clear that the fact that observation reports are expressed using
concepts derived from a theory has no effect on the capacity of nature to
say NO to a conjecture. Most notably, the illusion is not affected by the knowledge that it is an illusion, or
by knowledge of the theory of illusions. When is observation using ordinary human senses reliable, and when is it not?
2. This claim could be hedged more, but the basic idea is clear. Science
is an attempt to exploit this contact between our minds and the world, and
science is also motivated by the limitations that result from our relations
to the world; we need science because much of the world is not accessible
to ordinary observation. Science works by taking theoretical ideas and trying to find ways to expose them to observation. For normative naturalism, see Laudan 1987. Neither is fundamental, and the special features of science are due to an interaction between the two. In a case of theft or plagiarism,
the only person harmed is the one stolen from. Ideas are shared freely (though not before they are in publishable form). Science changes via processes of variation and selection, just as biological populations do. But of course, this is not how things usually work. There are cases where you will do best to join
the more promising program even though your joining makes little or no
difference to its chance of success. The overall
picture is clear, though. Science attempts to exploit
the contact with the world that humans have via experience, using this contact to explore and assess hypotheses about the world. If it is real, this exclusion may have epistemological consequences. We do not know how fragile the
social structure of science might be.

172 Chapter Eleven

In any case, this chapter and the previous one have introduced some of
the main themes in naturalistic philosophy of science. Our world, the world we all live in and interact with. If we say
that scientiﬁc realism does assume common-sense realism, we seem to be
committed to holding on to an everyday, unreﬂective picture of the world,
regardless of what science ends up saying. We should not think that
this question is one to be settled solely by the historical track record. We do not ﬁnd ourselves with powerful mathematical formalisms
that are hard to interpret. Theories will
do well or badly partly because of their relations to the world in which they

Scientific Realism 179

are used and investigated. Many sociologists of science have certainly opposed it, including Latour. So does Laudan. Feyerabend
is hard to assess. Empiricists believe that
our senses provide us with our only source of factual knowledge. Language and thought just cannot “reach” that far. The phenomenal world is the world as it appears to
us. The phenomenal world is knowable, but it is partly our creation. It does
not exist independently of the structure of our minds.
This kind of picture has often seemed appealing to philosophers who
want to deny scientiﬁc realism but do so in a moderate way. There
are various reasons, but I will venture some meta-sociology here—sociology of the sociology of science. Theories that do this
are “empirically adequate.” An empirically adequate theory might also describe the hidden structure of reality, but whether or not it does so is of no
interest to science. So far, our views seem compatible. There are several issues to consider.
One has to do with the “representational vehicles,” or representational media, used by science. Science does express hypotheses about the world using
sentences in language, either ordinary language or technical extensions of
ordinary language. We should not replace a language-based
analysis of all science with a model-based analysis. But not all science is like this. These models are written
down, of course. That will sound like a radical position, and so it is. Science aims to tell us, and often succeeds in telling
us, what the world is like. Science apparently seeks to explain as well as describe. Empiricists have often seen science, most fundamentally, as
a system of rules for predicting experience. Theories are often preferred by scientists because they seem to yield good explanations of puzzling phenomena. So far, so good. Symptoms can be used to predict, but they
cannot be used to explain. Empiricists have often tried to understand science without supposing that science concerns itself with alleged hidden connections of that
kind. Science constantly strives to reduce the number
of things that we must accept as fundamental. We do not have to choose. There are
some explanations that are at least close to what Hempel had in mind. Causation is sometimes
called, half jokingly, “the cement of the universe” (Mackie 1980; the phrase
was ﬁrst used by Hume [(1740) 1978]). . .”). These theories were not focused on the problem of
conﬁrmation in the way logical empiricism was. It is common to
think that it is not too hard to interpret probabilities of the form P(e|h), the
likelihoods. At least, that is how things work according to strict subjectivism. . .). One induction concludes that all emeralds are green, and the other concludes that all emeralds are grue. This argument might not be very good, however. (As always, such an argument is only as good as its
premises.) There are two ways in
which a nondeductive element can be introduced. It should not
be made too central, though. Neither of these can be used, without further assumptions, to answer either of the raven questions. It is just one data point, but it is a nonblack thing that turned out not
to be a raven. If we see a black
raven in a random sample of ravens, it is informative. It is just one data
point, but it is part of a sample that can answer our questions. These methods can be very powerful, but they can only
be used when some assumptions hold about the testing situation. So we have a big pile of emeralds, all of which are
grue. 7) and Kitcher (1993, chap. These three “isms”
have each been explored and, in some form, defended. There
are conﬂicts between them, or at least between some of the pairs. These mechanisms
respond to physical stimuli caused by objects and events in our environments. We should not think in terms
of two domains in reality, one accessible and one mysterious. This access to the world is constantly
being expanded, as our technology improves. In thinking about this problem, return to the simpler case of perception itself. In a broad sense, that is what science is all about. Or, more accurately, we seem to ﬁnd a couple of different balances. Feyerabend thought that recent science had lost its balance with
respect to the relation between imaginative and pedestrian work, as we saw

226 Chapter Fifteen

in chapter 7. Empiricist ideas are not just
vague and incomplete; they get it wrong. Empiricist views have no resources to describe the complex balances found in scientiﬁc work, especially balances found in the social organization of science. Empiricism is often summarized by saying that the only source of knowledge is experience.
But what is this talk of “sources” doing here? Objective inﬂuences on belief are
contrasted with subjective inﬂuences. Science counts as objective if it is a process in which belief and theory change are controlled by contact with real
things in the world. It is crude, and it tends to suggest false dichotomies. Are
we responsible for what we know, or is the world responsible for it? Ideas are assessed not in terms of their origins, but in terms of
how they stand up to testing. Science is open-minded, anti-authoritarian,
and ﬂexible.” Nice and simple. . . . Nonetheless, I
think the argument is erroneous. It does “lose the wood for the trees,” as
the saying goes. Theories of testing and evidence are in vastly better shape than
they were ﬁfty years ago. So a “strong” version of a view (empiricism, realism, etc.) S. Peirce. (2.3, 2.4, 2.5)
Anomaly. In Kuhn’s theory of science, an anomaly is a puzzle that resists solution by
the methods of normal science. A word with
many meanings. (4.2, 4.6)
Eliminative Inference. There are
also empiricist theories of language, which connect the meanings of words with experience or some kind of observational testing. Whatever is being explained, in an explanation. Whatever is doing the explaining, in an explanation. There are many terms for this idea or
ideas like it, including “abductive inference,” “inference to the best explanation,” “explanatory induction,” and “theoretical induction.”
In this book I treat this category as possibly overlapping with the category of eliminative inference. These might be beliefs about one’s own current experiences, perhaps. (10.1, 10.2)
Holism. There are many senses of this term. (12.4, 12.6)
Likelihoods. A word with many senses, leading to frequent confusion. An approach to philosophy that emphasizes the links (often, the “continuity”) between philosophy and science. In Kuhn’s theory of science, normal science is the orderly form of science guided by a paradigm. Most science, for Kuhn, is normal science. (2.3, 8.4)
Paradigm. Science typically involves ongoing competition between rival research programs in each ﬁeld. There are some differences, however, and Laudan’s concept is probably more
useful. (I said “matching” just now,
but that does not seem to help much either.) (2.3, 2.4)

(See Section 15.1.1.1. Now, let us describe the
purpose of the book in a more methodical way. The key feature of a digital communication system is that it deals with a finite set of discrete messages, in contrast to an analog communication system in
which messages are defined on a continuum. Signals and key processing steps are
traced from the information source through the transmitter, channel, receiver, and
ultimately to the information sink. Here, we deal with applications, such as mobile radios, where characterization of the channel is much more involved than that of a nonfading one. A new section, Appendix E, has been added to serve
as a short tutorial on s-domain, z-domain, and digital filtering. I have received an abundance of such assistance, for which I am deeply grateful. Finally, I am extremely grateful to my wife, Gwen, for her encouragement, devotion, and valuable advice.

Disc Structure
There is a large number of cylinders which are concentric.
Each cylinder has a vertically stacked set of tracks.
Each track is divided into a number of sectors.
Newer discs have zones and tracks in outer zones have larger
number of sectors than those in inner zones. Outer zones have
around 100 sectors per track.
Similarly, the number of cylinders per disc has also been
increasing and can be several thousands.
